description.plain:
The Beach Boys are one of the world’s best-selling bands of all time and the first American pop band to reach the 50-year milestone. Their vocal harmonies are among the most unmistakable and enduring of the rock and roll era.

Formed in 1961 in Hawthorne, California, by Brian Wilson, his two brothers Carl and Dennis, their cousin Mike Love, and classmate Al Jardine, the group’s first single “Surfin'” got them signed to Capitol Records and they quickly became one of the most popular and successful artists of the surf music craze of the 1960s. From 1962 to 1966, The Beach Boys scored over twenty top 40 hits in the US including the chart-toppers “I Get Around”, “Help Me Rhonda” & “Good Vibrations” along with the top 5’s “Surfin USA”, “Fun, Fun, Fun”, “California Girls”, “Barbara Ann” & “Sloop John B”. Several of the band’s singles also found top 40 success in Canada, Australia, Sweden and the UK. In 1965, de facto leader Brian Wilson suffered a mental breakdown due to the stress of writing, producing & touring combined with substance abuse issues, causing him to step down and stop traveling with the band on tour.

Inspired by producer Phil Spector and The Beatles' Rubber Soul, Brian focused on studio work, determined to keep the group relevant as the surf music scene was fading with their 1966 album Pet Sounds. Despite tension between members in the studio about this new direction, lack of faith from the record label, mixed reviews, and comparatively lukewarm reception initially in the US, the album still found massive success in the UK and earned accolades from fellow artists including The Beatles, who acknowledged that the album was their inspiration to further push the boundaries of pop music with their landmark album Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band. Eventually Pet Sounds would be acknowledged as one of the greatest albums ever recorded by several media outlets like The Times, Mojo Magazine, The Guardian, VH1, BBC and Rolling Stone.

Brian’s condition continued to deteriorate in the late 1960s, so other members contributed to songwriting through the 1970s with little chart success. Only three singles would reach the US top 20 for the entire decade, two of them being collaborative efforts with popular acts of the time. However, the band soldiered on as a lucrative touring act.

The 1980s were also a rough time for The Beach Boys with Brian’s psychiatrist discouraging him to have contact with other members, and Dennis' death in 1983 while swimming intoxicated. Their two biggest hits between 1980 and 1987 came from simply following popular trends of the time. “The Beach Boys Medley” took advantage of the Stars On 45/Hooked On Classics phenomenon of the early 80s, and a collaborative cover of “Wipe Out” with The Fat Boys was an effort to jump on the new trend of combining rock with hip-hop that had recently been established by the top 5 success of Aerosmith & Run DMC’s reinterpretation of “Walk This Way”.

It wasn’t until 1988’s Grammy-nominated “Kokomo” that The Beach Boys' rediscovered massive chart success around the world on their own merits, reaching #1 in the US, Japan and Australia and the top 10 in Canada and Germany. That same year, the band was inducted into the Rock And Roll Hall Of Fame and received a Lifetime Achievement Grammy Award. However, success was short-lived as “Still Cruisin'” peaked near the bottom of the Hot 100 the following year and became the group’s last single to chart in the US. 1992’s Summer In Paradise was derided by fans and critics, became the band’s only album to not appear on the Billboard 200, and would be their last studio effort of original material for twenty years.

After Carl’s death in 1998, Brian did not seek to use the band name so Love and Jardine squabbled over the ownership of it. Love secured the right to tour as The Beach Boys, so Jardine formed various incarnations of a touring act without using The Beach Boys name. In 2012, Brian, Love and Jardine reunited, released their first new album of original material since 1992 with That’s Why God Made The Radio, and toured together for the first time since 1965 – joined by Bruce Johnston (who’d replaced Brian for touring in 1965) and David Marks (a neighborhood friend who had performed on the group’s earliest albums) to fill Carl and Dennis’s spots. Several compilations of old recordings, including live and unreleased material, have since been released regularly.

songs.full_title: Surfin' USA by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Surfin’ USA

description.plain:
“Surfin' U.S.A.” is notable for giving the Beach Boys their first widespread success with its title track, and for Brian Wilson’s increasing prowess in songwriting, as well as vocal arrangement. The fuller-sounding vocals were achieved using double tracking, creating The Beach Boys' own unique sound. As with “Surfin' Safari”, some have speculated that “Surfin' U.S.A.” was not produced by Nick Venet, the officially listed producer, but by Brian Wilson.

This track featured lyrics by Brian Wilson, who intentionally set them to the music of “Sweet Little Sixteen,” by Chuck Berry, as he was inspired by that song. However, under pressure from Berry’s publisher and with threats of lawsuit, Wilson’s father and manager, Murry Wilson, gave the copyright for the song to Arc Music, Berry’s publisher.

It’s notable that “Fun, Fun, Fun,” another hit for The Beach Boys, sampled heavily from another of Berry’s songs, “Johnny B. Goode.”

songs.full_title: God Only Knows by The Beach Boys
songs.title: God Only Knows

description.plain:
“God Only Knows” is a song by American rock band The Beach Boys. It is the eighth track on the group’s 11th studio album, Pet Sounds, and one of their most widely recognized songs.

“God Only Knows” was composed and produced by Brian Wilson. Tony Asher helped Brian with the lyrics. Carl Wilson sang lead, and Bruce Johnston sang harmony vocals with Brian in the outro.

The song broke new ground in many ways. It was one of the first commercial songs to use the word ‘God’ in its title. As producer, Brian Wilson used many unorthodox instruments, including the harpsichord and French horns that are heard in the song’s famous introduction.

Although The Beatles engaged in a friendly rivalry with the Beach Boys based on mutual respect, Paul McCartney called this song the best song ever written.

songs.full_title: Wouldn't It Be Nice by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Wouldn’t It Be Nice

description.plain:
The opening track of Pet Sounds was later released as the  albums' third single with “God Only Knows” as its B-Side.

Listen for the rockin' accordions and the ethereal guitars in the introduction. Tony and I had visualized a scene. We had a feeling in our hearts, like a vibration. We put it into music, and it found its way onto tape. We really felt good about that record.
- Brian Wilson

The song was written with young people in mind and expresses the “never grow old” mentality.

Wouldn’t It Be Nice' was not a real long song, but it’s a very ‘up’ song. It expresses the frustrations of youth, what you can’t have, what you really want and you have to wait for it. The need to have the freedom to live with somebody. The idea is, the more we talk about it, the more we want it, but let’s talk about it anyway.
- Brian Wilson

songs.lyrics:
[Verse 1: Brian Wilson]
Wouldn't it be nice if we were older?
Then we wouldn't have to wait so long
And wouldn't it be nice to live together
In the kind of world where we belong?
[Chorus: Brian Wilson]
You know it's gonna make it that much better
When we can say goodnight and stay together

[Verse 2: Brian Wilson]
Wouldn't it be nice if we could wake up
In the morning when the day is new?
After having spent the day together
Hold each other close the whole night through

[Chorus: Brian Wilson]
But happy times together we've been spending
I wish that every kiss was never-ending
Oh, wouldn't it be nice?

[Bridge: Mike Love, Brian Wilson, Carl Wilson]
Maybe if we think and wish and hope and pray, it might come true
Oh, baby, then there wouldn't be a single thing we couldn't do
Oh, we could be married (Oh, we could be married)
And then we'd be happy (And then we'd be happy)
Oh, wouldn't it be nice?
[Chorus: Brian Wilson]
You know it seems the more we talk about it
It only makes it worse to live without it
But let's talk about it
But wouldn't it be nice?

[Outro: Mike Love]
Goodnight, my baby
Sleep tight, my baby
Goodnight, my baby
Sleep tight, my baby

songs.full_title: Good Vibrations by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Good Vibrations

description.plain:
The Beach Boys' Brian Wilson recounted the genesis of the title “Good Vibrations” in his 1995 biopic, I Just Wasn’t Made for These Times, and at other times. When he was a child, his mother told him that dogs could pick up “vibrations” from people, so that the dog would bark at “bad vibrations”. Wilson turned this into the general idea of vibrations (and Mike Love putting “good” in front of vibrations), and developed the idea of people being able to do the same with emotions.

This song is revolutionary in a couple of ways. Firstly, the song is a for the time unusual form:
A B A' B C D B E
There is a lot of new material (C, D and E), where most previous songs only had A’s and B’s and sometimes a bridge. Furthermore, these new parts are not in obvious ways musically connected to previous parts.
Second, there is a ton of instruments that were completely new to this type of music, most notably an Electro-Theremin. This song and the album Pet Sounds in general greatly influenced the Beatles, which resulted in Sgt. Pepper.

songs.full_title: Kokomo by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Kokomo

description.plain:
“Kokomo” is a song written by John Phillips, Scott McKenzie, Mike Love and Terry Melcher and recorded by The Beach Boys in spring 1988. Its lyrics describe two lovers taking a trip to a relaxing Caribbean island called Kokomo.

It was released as a single on July 18, 1988 by Elektra Records and became a No. 1 Hit in the United States, Japan and Australia (where it topped for about two months).

songs.full_title: Sloop John B by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Sloop John B

description.plain:
“Sloop John B” is the seventh track on The Beach Boys' Pet Sounds album and was also a single which was released in 1966 on Capitol Records.

 It was originally a traditional West Indies folk song, “The John B. Sails,” taken from a collection by Carl Sandburg (1927).

The Beach Boys version of “Sloop John B.” was ranked #271 (#276 in the 2017 version) on Rolling Stone’s list of The 500 Greatest Songs of All Time.

While the song’s music exhibits the typical surfer vibes the Beach Boys are known for, its lyrical content sheds a rather critical light on the tropical island motive often implemented and glorified by the band in their songs. This possible self-reflection ties in with the general theme of melancholy throughout the album, showing a more mature approach to life and to song-writing.

songs.full_title: California Girls by The Beach Boys
songs.title: California Girls

description.plain:
“California Girls” is a song by American rock band The Beach Boys, featured on their ninth studio album Summer Days (And Summer Nights!!) (1965). Written by band-members Brian Wilson (who conceived the song during an LSD trip) and Mike Love, the song features contrasting verse-chorus form. Upon its release as a single, “California Girls” reached #3 on the Billboard Hot 100.

It is one of The Beach Boys' most famous songs and has been included on countless greatest hits compilations. The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame included the song in its of the “500 Songs that Shaped Rock and Roll.” In 2004, Rolling Stone magazine ranked it 72nd on its list of the “500 Greatest Songs of All Time.”

songs.full_title: I Get Around by The Beach Boys
songs.title: I Get Around

description.plain:
“I Get Around” features a combination of surf guitars and doo-wop harmonies. Mike Love sings lead vocal on the verses, and sings the opening lines of the first chorus. Brian Wilson performs the rest of the lead vocals on the choruses. The driving bass line that carries the song was played by then unknown studio musician, Glen Campbell.

Released in 1964, “I Get Around” was the first Beach Boys song to #1 on the Billboard Pop charts.

songs.full_title: Surf's Up by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Surf’s Up

description.plain:
Lyricist Van Dyke Parks was sort of the Cam'ron of the Laurel Canyon psychedelia scene, treading a fine line between playful brilliance and cloying nonsense. In case you still needed convincing VDP is a genius, how ‘bout that Wikipedia entry! “Phil Spector meant nothing to me”? SO HARD.


Speaking on them in 1995, “I knew they didn’t surf.…I felt some resentment about [them], and I had been a fan of Four Freshmen and 5 Trombones.…Instinctively, I was not a Beach Boy fan. ‘Something really dumb about it.’” He added that, “I loved Pet Sounds, you see. I came back to love them, and thought they had done a great job. It seemed to me that they would be fine in fighting spirit to take on this challenge of wresting that trophy out of the hands of those interlopers.” Parks has gone on to call Wilson “the biggest event of that era,” and adds, “He was the force. Real convincing. He made music that could be enjoyed beyond its time. Phil Spector meant nothing to me—I thought his sound was just smoke and mirrors. People who said Pet Sounds was bastardizing classical music led very sheltered childhoods. That’s a bunch of bullshit. Brian Wilson was not imitative, he was inventive; for people who don’t write songs, it’s hard to understand how inventive he really was.”

Parks first became acquainted with Brian Wilson sometime in mid-1965, when David Crosby invited Parks to Wilson’s home to hear a four-track dub of the Beach Boys' forthcoming “Sloop John B” single. In February 1966, both Parks and Wilson reconnected at a lawn party thrown by Terry Melcher. In Wilson’s mostly ghostwritten 1993 autobiography, it was said that he gave his first impressions of Parks as being “a skinny kid with a unique perspective”, and that he “had a fondness for amphetamines” at the time. Parks hesitantly confirmed this, but added “Those were his amphetamines. They were in his medicine cabinet. I’d never had amphetamines. I was working for Brian Wilson at 3:30 AM when he wanted to have his amphetamines.”


Composer Brian Wilson wrote the gorgeous score behind it, which is probably the closest America will ever get to its own Wagnerian epic.

People who said Pet Sounds was bastardizing classical music led very sheltered childhoods. That’s a bunch of bullshit. Brian Wilson was not imitative, he was inventive; for people who don’t write songs, it’s hard to understand how inventive he really was.”

Parks first became acquainted with Brian Wilson sometime in mid-1965, when David Crosby invited Parks to Wilson’s home to hear a four-track dub of the Beach Boys' forthcoming “Sloop John B” single. In February 1966, both Parks and Wilson reconnected at a lawn party thrown by Terry Melcher. In Wilson’s mostly ghostwritten 1993 autobiography, it was said that he gave his first impressions of Parks as being “a skinny kid with a unique perspective”, and that he “had a fondness for amphetamines” at the time. Parks hesitantly confirmed this, but added “Those were his amphetamines. They were in his medicine cabinet. I’d never had amphetamines. I was working for Brian Wilson at 3:30 AM when he wanted to have his amphetamines.”


Composer Brian Wilson wrote the gorgeous score behind it, which is probably the closest America will ever get to its own Wagnerian epic.

songs.full_title: In My Room by The Beach Boys
songs.title: In My Room

description.plain:
It was a powerful song to choose as a B Side.

In 2008 Mojo’s Mat Snow said of “In My Room”:
“Hearing the music of Brian Wilson [evokes] the decades of breakdown, withdrawal and desolation even in his most carefree music before his mind crashed in 1967; how tragic with foreboding does ‘In My Room’ sound when you recall the recluse he was to become?”

Nevertheless, Curt Kurnutt calls for an unbiased reading of the song, which could be understood as “reflecting the adolescent propensity for withdrawal or even what in 1963 was for many American teenagers the first-generation luxury of having a bedroom or basement of one’s own to retreat to.”

songs.full_title: Don't Worry Baby by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Don’t Worry Baby

description.plain:
Brian Wilson wrote “Don’t Worry Baby” as a male counter part to The Ronettes' “Be My Baby”, and has talked about that song’s profound effect on him.

Lyrically, the song focuses on the singer’s reluctance to partake in a car race and his girlfriend’s reassurance that everything will be fine in the end. The song’s point of view is unusual, especially considering the typical fearless devotion and love of racing cars found in other Beach Boys songs from this period (i.e. “I Get Around”).

songs.full_title: Surfin' Safari by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Surfin’ Safari

description.plain:
Surfin' Safari, originally released in 1962, was the second song ever released by The Beach Boys. Released as a single and backed by the song “409”, the song peaked at number 14 on the Billboard Hot 100 Chart, and would remain on the chart for 17 weeks. The song later featured prominently on The Beach Boys debut album of the same name.

In 2014, Billboard ranked the song #1 in its list of  “Top 30 Summer Songs”.

In classic Beach Boys style, the song focuses on three subjects: surfing, women, and cars. In “Surfin' Safari”, the former takes precedence.

Though on the surface a simple verse-chorus form song about a surf adventure, the song also does an excellent job of exploring the broad momentum that surf culture was gaining in California in the 1960s.

songs.full_title: I Just Wasn't Made for These Times by The Beach Boys
songs.title: I Just Wasn’t Made for These Times
songs.title_with_featured: I Just Wasn't Made for These Times

description.plain:
The lyrics were written by Brian Wilson and Tony Asher about the ruminations on romance and the loss of innocence involved in growing up.
Wilson stated in his autobiography that “I Just Wasn’t Made for These Times” was telling a self-portrait of his troubled psyche and that he was too advanced for his time.

songs.full_title: That's Not Me by The Beach Boys
songs.title: That’s Not Me

description.plain:
“That’s Not Me” is a song by the American rock band The Beach Boys, taken from their 1966 album Pet Sounds. It is the third track on the album.

Mike Love takes the lead vocals here and it should also be noted that it’s the only song on the album Pet Sounds where the majority of the instruments are played only by the band members.

songs.full_title: Fun, Fun, Fun by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Fun, Fun, Fun

description.plain:
A classic Beach Boys song that features the carefree, California-inspired themes that were their signature, “Fun, Fun, Fun” peaked at #5 on the Billboard Hot 100 in 1964, and eventually appeared on their album Shut Down Volume 2.

The song follows a high-spirited girl who takes her dad’s T-bird to presumably go to the library, but actually goes to the burger stand to have fun. The song may have been inspired by Shirley England and her own escapades in the 1960s. According to England, the band was at her father’s radio station while she was hanging around, complaining about how her father had punished her and taken away her driving privileges the day prior.

songs.full_title: You Still Believe in Me by The Beach Boys
songs.title: You Still Believe in Me

description.plain:
A dream-like introduction to this song is produced by Brian and Asher. One person was on the keys while someone was holding the strings in the piano, creating the unique sound heard here.

We were trying to do something that would sound sort of, I guess, like a harpsichord but a little more ethereal than that. I am plucking the strings by leaning inside the piano and Brian is holding down the notes on the keyboard so they will ring when I pluck them. I plucked the strings with paper clips, hairpins, bobby pins and several others things until Brian got the sound he wanted

– liner notes

It was one of the first songs Brian started on and had a childhood theme, until Tony Asher came. This is evident from the bicycle horn heard throughout the song.

songs.full_title: Heroes and Villains by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Heroes and Villains

description.plain:
To some an unfinished masterpiece, to others just unfinished, the Beach Boys' “Heroes and Villains” was to be the centerpiece of the abandoned Smile album.

Consumed by the prospect of overtopping the success of “Good Vibrations” and besting the Beatles, Brian Wilson dragged the band through a grueling 20 session recording process. Wilson’s chosen lyricist, the famed Van Dyke Parks, was not popular with the other members of the band. During one studio session, Mike Love reportedly berated Parks for his cryptic lyrics, while Brian Wilson cowered in the booth.

Many at the time thought the song was an allegory about the Vietnam War, but Van Dyke Parks explained that that particular conflict wasn’t on his mind:

‘Heroes And Villains’ had nothing to do with Vietnam, but with the Indian thing we were trying to exculpate our guilt, to atone for what we had done to the aborigines of our own place… To me, ‘Heroes And Villains’ sounds like a ballad out of the Southwest. That’s what it was intended to be—as good as any of those—and, really, to be a ballad. This Spanish and Indian fascination is a big chapter in Californian history, and that’s what it’s supposed to be—historically reflective, to reflect this place. I think it did it.

Brian Wilson’s then-wife Marilyn Robinson had a different interpretation:

There are so many screwed-up people in the music industry. The good guys and the bad guys. That’s one thing Brian had in mind when they did ‘Heroes and Villains.’

Despite the time and energy spent on the song, at some point Brian Wilson lost faith and seemed to give up. The Beach Boys' Al Jardine thought Wilson deliberately sabotaged the record when it was clear it wouldn’t meet his high expectations:

We recorded a pale facsimile of ‘Heroes and Villains,’ replete with discordant transitions. Brian reinvented the song for this record. He purposefully under-produced the song. It was lost because Brian wanted it to be lost. He was no longer interested in pursuing number one.

The version that was released sounds extremely rough and incomplete, but it still managed to peak at #12 on the Billboard Hot 100, a testament to the strength of the Beach Boys brand at the time. But the relatively poor showing compared to their #1 smash “Good Vibrations” put the final nail in the coffin of Smile; Wilson wouldn’t release a completed version of the album until 2004.

songs.full_title: Caroline, No by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Caroline, No

description.plain:
The ultimate song on Pet Sounds, “Caroline, No” was also Brian Wilson’s first (and only) single to be released under his own name on the Capitol label.

The moody ballad epitomizes the spirit of Pet Sounds: an unwillingly world-wise lover bemoans the changes undergone in his love affair. The song evokes this mood with the simple image of a girl cutting her hair.



The name of the song is based on misheard words:

Per the Rolling Stone:

Wilson told Asher about a girl he’d liked in high school named Carol, and Asher responded with “Oh, Carol, I know.” But Wilson heard it as “Caroline, no” and dashed off the rest of the song while stoned.

songs.full_title: Don't Talk (Put Your Head on My Shoulder) by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Don’t Talk (Put Your Head on My Shoulder)
songs.title_with_featured: Don't Talk (Put Your Head on My Shoulder)

description.plain:
Brian Wilson called this Pet Sounds number “[o]ne of the sweetest songs I ever sang…The innocence of youth in my voice, of being young and childlike.  I think that’s what people liked”

Bassist on the session Carol Kaye said of the music:

Nice chords changes…almost classical…Lots of suspensions and close harmonies, something Brian was getting more and more into

songs.full_title: I Know There's an Answer by The Beach Boys
songs.title: I Know There’s an Answer

description.plain:
“I Know There’s an Answer” is a song by the American rock band The Beach Boys, taken from their 1966 album Pet Sounds. It is the ninth track on the album. The song was composed and produced by Brian Wilson with the lyrics by Terry Sachen and Mike Love.

The song was written during Brian’s second acid trip. Wilson later stated “Yeah. I had taken a few drugs, and I had gotten into that kind of thing. I guess it just came up naturally.” The song was originally named “Hang on to Your Ego”, but the lyric of the chorus was changed after concerns that it was LSD-related.

songs.full_title: Barbara Ann by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Barbara Ann

description.plain:
The cover for a 1961 moderately successful doo wop song by The Regents, the song was recorded in  the studio while partying with friends, and recruiting Dean Torrance, half of the fellow surfing songs duo Jan and Dean of the “Dead Man Curve” (which Brian Wilson helped write!) fame to sing the lead.

It became a huge hit (topped the charts in early 1966) and a favorite dance party number.



The whole album Beach Boys Party was recorded in a studio party, as heard in the the bridge and the extended outro (see annotations), the album was recorded in response to the demand by Capitol records to have an album out for the the 1965 holiday season.



The album included none of their original songs, covering everything from the Beatles to bob Dylan, all to a dance beat.

This was recorded at the time that Brian Wilson and the band were working on their masterpiece concept album, Pet Sounds.

songs.full_title: Never Learn Not to Love by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Never Learn Not to Love

description.plain:
Reportedly adapted from “Cease to Exist,” a song written for the Beach Boys by Charles Manson, who had befriended the band, particulalry Dennis Wilson. Notably, the Beach Boys changed Manson’s original lyric “cease to exist” to “cease to resist” to tone it down.



The story of this song inspired the first line of the Pixies “Wave of Mutilation.”

songs.full_title: Let’s Go Away for a While by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Let’s Go Away for a While
songs.title_with_featured: Let’s Go Away for a While

description.plain:
Tony Asher has explained the esoteric origins of this song:

There was an album out called How to Speak Hip […] a lampooning of the language instruction albums. I played it for Brian, and it destroyed him, killed him. Brian picked up a couple of references on the album. One of them was this hip character that said if everyone were ‘laid back and cool, then we’d have world peace.’ So Brian started going around saying, ‘Hey, would somebody get me a candy bar, and then we’ll have world peace.’. [Brian] even made an acetate disc with a label on it with the title. He talked about calling Let’s Go Away For Awhile ‘And Then We’ll Have World Peace.’"

Brian is quoted as calling this track, “the most satisfying piece of music [he] ever made.”


Source – Pet Sounds Track Notes

songs.full_title: Feel Flows by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Feel Flows

description.plain: In 1971 Carl Wilson and The Beach Boys manager Jack Rieley came together and wrote this song. The song is about his brother Brian being depressed and tired of being that way. It discusses it from his point of view, trying to hide away from the depression and trying to be more positive. Even though he’s trying to change for the better, his feelings of sadness still come out and being sad is inevitable. He tries to sit back and cleanse himself so he relaxes trying to gain a piece of mind and a sense of clarity hoping that everything is going to be alright.

songs.title: Pet Sounds

description.plain: This is the second to last song on Pet Sounds. The song was originally written for a James Bond film supposedly, and the title Brian Wilson had planned for it was called “Run James Run”. However, it never made it to a film, and was changed to “Pet Sounds” and was put on the album.

songs.full_title: Surfer Girl by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Surfer Girl

description.plain: Brian explained the genesis of the song: “Back in 1961, I’d never written a song in my life. I was nineteen years old. And I put myself to the test in my car one day. I was actually driving to a hot dog stand, and I actually created a melody in my head without being able to hear it on a piano. I sang it to myself; I didn’t even sing it out loud in the car. When I got home that day, I finished the song, wrote the bridge, put the harmonies together and called it ‘Surfer Girl’.”

songs.full_title: Shut Down by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Shut Down

description.plain:
“Shut Down” is the second hot-rod song released by the Beach Boys. As with tradition for the band at the time, it was the B-side to a surf song, in this case “Surfin' U.S.A”.

The song details a street race between a Super-Stock 413 Dodge Dart and a fuel-injected Chevrolet Corvette Stingray, the latter being driven by the song’s protagonist.

annotatable.link_title: Shut Down by The Beach Boys
annotatable.title: Shut Down

body.plain:
“Shut Down” is the second hot-rod song released by the Beach Boys. As with tradition for the band at the time, it was the B-side to a surf song, in this case “Surfin' U.S.A”.

The song details a street race between a Super-Stock 413 Dodge Dart and a fuel-injected Chevrolet Corvette Stingray, the latter being driven by the song’s protagonist.

songs.lyrics:
[Chorus]
Tach it up, tach it up
Buddy going to shut you down

[Verse 1]
It happened on the strip where the road is wide
(Oooo rev it up now)
Two cool shorts standing side by side
(Oooo rev it up now)
Yeah, my fuel injected Stingray and a four-thirteen
(Oooo rev it up now)
Revving up our engines and it sounds real mean
(Oooo rev it up now)

[Chorus]
Tach it up, tach it up
Buddy going to shut you down

[Verse 2]
Declining numbers at an even rate
(Oooo moving out now)
At the count of one we both accelerate
(Oooo moving out now)
My Stingray is light the slicks are starting to spin
(Oooo moving out now)
But the four-thirteen's really digging in
(Oooo moving out now)
Got to be cool now, power shift - here we go
[Bridge]
Superstock Dart is winding out in low
But my fuel injected Stingray's really starting to go
To get the traction I'm riding the clutch
My pressure plate's burning that machine's too much

[Verse 3]
Pedal's to the floor hear the dual quads drink
(Oooo pump it up now)
And now the four-thirteen's lead is starting to shrink
(Oooo pump it up now)
He's hot with ram induction but it's understood
(Oooo pump it up now)
I got a fuel injected engine sitting under my hood
(Oooo pump it up now)

[Outro]
Shut it off, shut it off buddy now I shut you down
Shut it off, shut it off buddy now I shut you down
Shut it off, shut it off buddy now I shut you down
Shut it off, shut it off buddy now I shut you down

songs.lyrics:
[Verse 1]

Seldom stumble, never crumble

Never ending, unrelenting
Heartbreak searing, always fearing
Never caring, persevering
Sail on, sail on, sailor

[Verse 3]
I work the seaways, the gale-swept seaways

Uninspired, drenched and tired
Wail on, wail on, sailor
[Chorus 2]
Always needing, even bleeding
Never feeding all my feelings
Damn the thunder, must I blunder
There's no wonder all I'm under
Stop the crying and the lying
And the sighing and my dying
Sail on, sail on sailor

[Outro]
Sail on, sail on sailor
Sail on, sail on sailor
Sail on, sail on sailor

songs.full_title: Help Me, Rhonda by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Help Me, Rhonda

description.plain:
A catchy tune and repetitive chorus make up “Help Me Rhonda”, a song about a man who begs a woman named Rhonda to “help him” in light of his fiancée cheating on him.

Originally recorded for an earlier album, “Help Me Rhonda” in its most popular form appears on the album Summer Days (and Summer Nights), and hit #1 on the Billboard Hot 100 in May of 1965..

The original version, entitled “Help me Ronda”, had an interesting recording session, to say the least. While recording, The Beach Boys' manager (and father to three members), Murray Wilson, barged in drunk, interrupting the session. An ensuing argument between father and son was captured on the tapes from the session, showcasing a confident-sounding Brian Wilson as he confronts his father, whose bad behavior has been documented elsewhere.

The audio from this original session can be listened to here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_bxfR-Vuo8Y

songs.full_title: Be True to Your School by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Be True to Your School

description.plain:
“Be True To Your School” is the third track on Little Deuce Coupe and one of the singles taken from the album. It was written by Brian Wilson and Mike Love with lead vocals by Mike. The song features the melody from the Hawthorne High School’s fight song, which in turn uses the same melody as the University of Wisconsin’s fight song “Oh, Wisconsin.”

There are two versions of this song: the album version, and the single version, which added cheerleader yells by Honeys in between verses.

songs.full_title: Disney Girls (1957) by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Disney Girls (1957)

description.plain:
“Disney Girls (1957)” is the fourth single released from The Beach Boys album, Surf’s Up. It was written by Bruce Johnston, eventually becoming his signature song. Brian Wilson, who was falling into inactivity in the band at this point, approved of it in particular.

It lyrically and musically captures a sad dream of a happier life – the “Disney Girls” that don’t really exist.

Interestingly, despite the very timely title, it has simply become more relevant over the years as escapism has taken greater hold of people.

songs.full_title: A Day In The Life Of A Tree by The Beach Boys
songs.title: A Day In The Life Of A Tree
songs.title_with_featured: A Day In The Life Of A Tree

description.plain:
In this song tree is metaphor for human being. Same as the tree, we too, grow up, spend some time on the Earth and then slowly die.

We can see that in early days he was full of life, filled with joy and happiness, but as years went by and he got older, dark clouds appeared on the horizon. He realized that his best days are behind him and this caused sadness in him.

Song does great job at expressing sadness and depression in person. From lyrics, to pain in his voice, it greatly shows, how upset the person is over the fact, that he will never be young, strong and healthy again and that as every day passes, he is one day closer to inevitable death.

songs.full_title: Don't Go Near The Water by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Don’t Go Near The Water

description.plain:
“Don’t Go Near The Water” is an environmentalist song lamenting human pollution in water. The Beach Boys' manager Jack Rieley suggested the band make a political song to stay relevant.

The song, along with the album’s title and cover art, display a break with the band’s past obsession with all things surfing. In direct contrast with all the band’s previous songs about surfing and fun, they now advise to stay away from the water at all costs.

songs.full_title: When I Grow Up (To Be A Man) by The Beach Boys
songs.title: When I Grow Up (To Be A Man)
songs.title_with_featured: When I Grow Up (To Be A Man)

description.plain:
When I grow up (to be a man) is the fourth track on “Today!” It was written by Brian Wilson and Mike Love, with lead vocals by Mike.

The song deals with the topic of leaving childhood and entering adulthood. The singer ponders how much his adult self will change compared with his childhood self.

songs.full_title: Surfin' by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Surfin’

description.plain:
“Surfin'” was The Beach Boy’s first single ever released in November of 1961, with “Luau” on the B Side. The song also features on their full length debut Surfin' Safari. The song was not a huge radio hit, peaking at 75 on the US charts, but it was the first song to establish what became The Beach Boy’s iconic surf rock sound, and the single effectively launched their career.

The song discussed the themes that became ubiquitous in The Beach Boy’s repertoire; the carefree surf lifestyle combine with the simple verse/chorus format and upbeat tempo set the tone for what would become The Beach Boy’s iconic sound.

“Surfin'” was recorded when The Beach Boys were still signed with their first label, Candix, a now defunct small label, prior to signing with Capitol in 1962.

songs.full_title: Cabin Essence by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Cabin Essence

description.plain:
“Cabin Essence” is a track written by Brian Wilson and Van Dyke Parks for the Beach Boys' aborted Smile album. The song is comprised of three sections, sampled into a pattern to form the structure of a song. This song is highly controversial amongst Beach Boys fans, and is regarded as the tipping point in the Smile project, due to certain band members objection to it’s artistic lyrics. However, the song was later “finished” in 1969 by Carl Wilson for release on the Beach Boys' current album 20/20.

“Cabin Essence” is about westward expansion across the American continent. It sings about ranges and the trans-continental railroads, and also about the Chinese laborers who built them.

The verses of the song are made up of a track known as “Home On the Range” in it’s early production, and sing about the beautiful landscapes found out west.

The chorus' of the song are made up of a section known as “Who Ran the Iron Horse?”. The Beach Boys chant about the “Iron Horse” while Dennis Wilson raps about telephone lines and hobos crossing the continent with the trains.

The final section of the song is a fadeout known as “The Grande Coulee”. It sings about the Chinese laborers who worked on building the trans-continental railroads. One worker in particular looks up into the sky and sees a crow flying overhead. He then envisions himself as the crow, flying away in the endless American landscape (“Over and Over”).

songs.full_title: Student Demonstration Time by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Student Demonstration Time

description.plain:
“Student Demonstration Time” is perhaps most emblematic of the political nature of Surf’s Up. The track is effectively a retooling of “Riot in Cell Block Number 9.”

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0ZE-BOfRi80

The lyrics were altered to reference student protests, bringing awareness to the excessive police violence students were facing.

songs.full_title: Wonderful by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Wonderful

description.plain:
The ‘weird’ piano-like sound throughout the whole song is a harpsichord, popular in the 60’s especially for the baroque rock genre.

Instead of the strings getting struck by a hammer like a conventional piano, they are plucked which gives it the distinctive sound.

Although it’s widely reported that most (or some) people in the band didn’t like the whole SMiLE project, it can be heard on the SMiLE Sessions that Wonderful was one their favorite tracks.

The song seems to be about the loss of a girl’s innocence when she meets someone.

songs.full_title: The Warmth Of The Sun by The Beach Boys
songs.title: The Warmth Of The Sun

description.plain:
“The Warmth of the Sun”, a song written by Brian Wilson and Mike Love. Brian Wilson also produced the song, and the rest of the album. He also pioneered the use of adventurous chord changes in pop—"The Warmth of the Sun’s" transitions from C to A-minor to E-flat, were unheard of in 1964. It was released on their 1964 album Shut Down Volume 2 and also released on the B-side of their “Dance, Dance, Dance” single. Wilson and Love actually began to compose the song on November 22, 1963, the day of the assassination of John F. Kennedy. Although the two co-authors give different accounts of the timing and whether it was begun before or after the killing. The subsequent recording of the song was informed by the emotional shock felt by its authors in the wake of Kennedy’s death.
“The Warmth of the Sun” was started in the early morning hours of the same morning that President Kennedy was killed in Dallas. The melody was so haunting, sad, melancholy, that the only thing that I could think of lyrically was the loss of love, when interest slips and feelings aren’t reciprocated…though I wanted to have a silver lining on that cumulus nimbus cloud so I wrote the lyrics from the perspective of, “Yes, things have changed and love is no longer there, but the memory of it lingers like the Warmth of the Sun.”
I think it’s really impactful and memorable…one of my favorite songs from an emotional and personal point of view."

— Mike Love, 2007

“Dance Dance Dance” is the sixth track on “Today!” It was composed by Brian and Carl Wilson with lyrics by Brian Wilson and Mike Love.

The song is about a youth’s love for dancing, no matter what the occasion.

songs.lyrics:
[Verse 1: Mike Love]
After six hours of school I've had enough for the day
I hit the radio dial and turn it up all the way

[Chorus: Brian Wilson, Group, Mike Love]
I got to dance (Dance, dance, dance now the beat's really hot)
Right on the spot (Dance, dance, dance right there on the spot)
The beat's really hot (Dance, dance, dance now the beat's really hot)
(Dance) Dance, (dance) dance
(Dance) Dance, yeah!

[Verse 2: Mike Love]
When I feel put down I try to shake it off quick
With my chick by my side the radio does the trick

[Chorus: Brian Wilson, Group, Mike Love]
I got to dance (Dance, dance, dance now the beat's really hot)
Right on the spot (Dance, dance, dance right there on the spot)
The beat's really hot (Dance, dance, dance now the beat's really hot)
(Dance) Dance, (dance) dance
(Dance) Dance, yeah!
Oh my!

[Verse 3: Mike Love]
At a weekend dance we like to show up last
I play it cool when it's slow and jump it up when it's fast
[Chorus: Brian Wilson, Group, Mike Love]
I got to dance (Dance, dance, dance now the beat's really hot)
Right on the spot (Dance, dance, dance right there on the spot)
The beat's really hot (Dance, dance, dance now the beat's really hot)
(Dance) Dance, (dance) dance
(Dance) Dance, yeah!

[Outro: Brian Wilson, Group, Mike Love]
Ahhh (Dance, dance, dance now the beat's really hot)
Ahhhh (Dance, dance, dance right there on the spot)
Ahhhhhh, oooh (Dance, dance, dance now the beat's really hot)
(Dance) Dance, (dance) dance
(Dance) Dance, yeah!EmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.full_title: Do You Wanna Dance? by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Do You Wanna Dance?

description.plain: San Francisco’s Bobby Freeman, a full-blooded Choctaw, wrote and recorded the R&B smash hit “Do You Want to Dance” in 1958 when he was 17. Here, the Beach Boys give his classic song their full-throated magic harmonies and slangily changed the title.  While it was a mainstay of Freeman’s act, the song has also been covered by John Lennon and The Mamas & the Papas, Bette Midler and The Ramones.  The Beach Boys' version, released in 1965 as a single and also on The Beach Boys Today! LP, features Dennis Wilson on lead vocals.

But the 413's really diggin' in

Superstock Dodge is winding out in low
But my fuel injected Stingray's really startin' to go
To get the traction, I'm ridin' the clutch
My pressure plate's burnin', that machine's too much

songs.full_title: Cool, Cool Water by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Cool, Cool Water

description.plain: “Cool, Cool Water” is the final track off the Beach Boys' 1970 album Sunflower. The song originally branched from an earlier Brian Wilson composition titled “I Love To Say Dada”, and both songs are very similar in chord progressions and melodic hooks. The recordings for “Cool, Cool Water” were first attempted in June and October 1967 for Smiley Smile and Wild Honey. Three years later, an A&R executive at Warner Music, Lenny Waronker, heard the unfinished tape and convinced Brian Wilson to finish the track for Sunflower.

songs.full_title: Vega-Tables by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Vega-Tables

description.plain: The song was partly inspired by Wilson’s obsession with physical fitness in the late 1960s. In a contemporary article, he stated, “I want to turn people on to vegetables, good natural food, organic food. Health is an important element in spiritual enlightenment. But I do not want to be pompous about it, so we will engage in a satirical approach.”

songs.full_title: Wind Chimes by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Wind Chimes

description.plain: “Wind Chimes” is the eighth track on the Beach Boys' 1967 album Smiley Smile. The track is a remake of an earlier recording of the same song from the band’s aborted Smile album. This new version of the song contains sparser instrumentation and more advance vocal arrangements. The outro is taken from another earlier track from the Smile album known only as “Holidays”.

songs.full_title: The Old Master Painter/You Are My Sunshine by The Beach Boys
songs.title: The Old Master Painter/You Are My Sunshine
songs.title_with_featured: The Old Master Painter/You Are My Sunshine

description.plain:
“The Old Master Painter” was a track for the Beach Boys abandoned studio album Smile. It is a medley that contains covers of two popular American folk songs, “The Old Master Painter”, and “You Are My Sunshine”. A third section near the end was written by Brian Wilson as a fadeout for the medley.

The track describes the loss of the narrator’s “Sunshine”, given to him by “The Old Master Painter” himself. At the end of the Sunshine section, the strings start descending, provoking the image of dripping ink lines on a painting.

songs.full_title: Hey Little Tomboy by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Hey Little Tomboy

description.plain: Written by Brian Wilson, Beach Boys biographer Peter Ames Carlin wrote that the song “reveled uncomfortably in an adolescent girl who is putting away her skateboard and baseball mitt in order to get hot and heavy with the swain portrayed by Mike [Love]. … [it] may be the most unsettling moment in the entire recorded history of the Beach Boys.”

songs.full_title: She's Goin' Bald by The Beach Boys
songs.title: She’s Goin’ Bald

description.plain:
“She’s Goin' Bald” is a remake of the musical section known as “He Gives Speeches” from the aborted SMiLE album. The opening section of the song is unchanged with only the the first verse containing original lyrics. The rest of the song is new material written during the Smiley Smile summer of ‘67.

Allegedly the song is about a girl who’s hair was accidentally ripped out by a boy who was receiving such an amazing blowjob from her.

songs.full_title: Heroes and Villains (Smile Sessions Version) by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Heroes and Villains (Smile Sessions Version)

description.plain:
“Heroes and Villains” was written by Brian Wilson and Van Dyke Parks. It was the first song written for the Smile project in 1966.

Wilson credits Parks with the title, while Parks credits Wilson, explaining: “I think he made that up. I think it was a great title, and he suggested it. To me, ‘Heroes And Villains’ sounds like a ballad out of the Southwest. That’s what it was intended to be—as good as any of those—and, really, to be a ballad. This Spanish and Indian fascination is a big chapter in Californian history, and that’s what it’s supposed to be—historically reflective, to reflect this place. I think it did it.”

Then-wife Marilyn Wilson said: “There are so many screwed-up people in the music industry. The good guys and the bad guys … That’s one thing Brian had in mind when they did ‘Heroes and Villains.’‘ The song was thought to have been written about the Vietnam War, but Parks clarified: ”'Heroes And Villains’ had nothing to do with Vietnam, but with the Indian thing we were trying to exculpate our guilt, to atone for what we had done to the aborigines of our own place. There’s a lot of things about belief in Smile, and its very question of belief is what was plaguing Brian at that time.

songs.full_title: She Knows Me Too Well by The Beach Boys
songs.title: She Knows Me Too Well

description.plain:
Yet another brilliantly introspective song by Brian Wilson, highly unusual and ahead of its time for 1964. A portrait of a jealous and cruel man, but with the partially redeeming quality of knowing he is wrong, even to the point of admitting he doesn’t deserve the woman who loves him. The conflicting emotions expressed fleshes out this individual as a fully realized character, rather than a one-dimensional, black and white, good or bad guy.

The chord progression of the chorus is suspiciously similar to the great hit from 1972 “Go All The Way” by The Raspberries, itself a very different song with very different parts, and yet…that chorus!
https://genius.com/Raspberries-go-all-the-way-lyrics

songs.full_title: Big Sur by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Big Sur

description.plain:
Big Sur is a song  that was originally written by vocalist Mike Love for an early version of The Beach Boy’s 17th studio album “Surf’s Up” which was called “Landlocked” at the time of the original recording of this song. It was omitted from the final release of Surf’s Up and was later included in their 19th studio “Holland” as a part of the “California Saga”, a group of three linked songs in the album.

The song describes Big Sur, a rugged stretch of California’s central coast between Carmel and San Simeon, as a beautiful place where the Singer and his lover wish to spend their lives in.

songs.lyrics:
Cashmere hills filled with evergreens
Flowin' from the clouds down to meet the sea
With the granite cliff
(Big Sur mount)
As a referee
Crimson sunsets and golden dawns
A mother deer with their newborn fawns
All under Big Sur skies
(Big Sur mount)
That's where I belong

Big Sur I've got plans for you
Me and mine are going to
Add ourselves to your lengthy list of lovers
(Big Sur mount)
And live in canyons covered in springtime green
Wild birds and flowers to be heard and seen
And with my old guitar
(Big Sur mount)
I'll make up songs to sing
Where bubbling springs from the mountainside
Join the Big Sur river to the oceanside
Where the kids can look for sea shells at low tide
(Big Sur mount)
Big Sur my astrology it says that I am made to be
Where the rugged mountain meets the water
(Big Sur mount)
And so while stars shine brightly from up above
The fog rolls in through a redwood grove
And to my dying fire I think I'll add a log
(Big Sur mount)

From time to time I must go away
But thoughts of Big Sur won't let me stay
Away from Big Sur

songs.full_title: Do You Like Worms? (Smile Sessions Version) by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Do You Like Worms? (Smile Sessions Version)
songs.title_with_featured: Do You Like Worms? (Smile Sessions Version)

description.plain:
“Do You Like Worms?” is a song by the Beach Boys from their 1967 aborted Smile album. The song’s production began in the fall of 1966, and was finished in early 1967. Due to the nature of band leader Brian Wilson’s production method of recording songs in sections, most of the completed sections of this song have been lost over time. What is left for us to hear today are early vocal overdubs and demo recordings edited together. A re-recorded version of this song with all of it’s original elements can be found in Brian Wilson’s “Roll Plymouth Rock”

“Do You Like Worms?” is a song about the arrival of European settlers onto the newly found American soil, and their subsequent invasion into the native’s land and culture.

songs.full_title: Child Is Father of the Man by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Child Is Father of the Man
songs.title_with_featured: Child Is Father of the Man

description.plain:
Another shorter track from the famed unfinished ‘Smile’ album, Child is Father of the Man forms part of the ‘life’ movement on the finished version completed by Brian Wilson in 2004, preceding the track ‘Surf’s Up.’ The lyrics are sparse, yet convey this particular section of the album’s theme of childhood and the transition to adulthood.
There’s a parallel between the loss of innocence occurring in the previous track on Smile, ‘Wonderful,’ and here, the act growing old setting the stage for a child’s experiences shaping who the child grows into as an adult. This loss of innocence is also explored in the subsequent song, ‘Surf’s Up,’ as well.

description.plain:
This song in particular is noted for its heavy Beatles influence, with many pointing out how this song sounds similar to “Ticket to Ride” from the Beatles own 1965 album “Help!”.

It is also notable for being one of the earliest Beach Boys songs where Carl Wilson sings the lead vocals.

songs.full_title: Marcella by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Marcella

description.plain:
Brian was the instigator behind this song, after being turned on by one of the masseuses at the massage parlor he frequently went to. Jack Rieley then came up with the idea of writing the song around that experience.

Originally, it and the other track on the album, “You Need a Mess of Help to Stand Alone” had lyrics originally written by Tandyn Almer. Jack rewrote the lyrics to both songs. However, while “Mess of Help” was credited to Brian and Jack, this track was credited to Brian, Jack and Tandyn, implying that some of the lyrics by Tandyn were kept in for the final recording.

songs.full_title: Brian's Back by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Brian’s Back

description.plain:
This is a somewhat clumsy but no less heartelt love letter from Mike Love to Brian Wilson. Anyone who knows the stories of their battles, trials (literally – they’ve sued each other) and tribulations might look upon this with a rather cynical eye as being bit of a rip off of Brian’s great ideas, which is particularly galling in light of the fact that Love often battled viciously against Wilson’s offbeat and adventurous forays beyond the realm of girls, cars and surfing.

It is because of this that many listeners, the majority of whom worship Brian (guilty) and hate Mike (for the most part, yeah) refuse to give Love any credit for possibly actually meaning what he says in the song. Despite my misgivings toward him, I do take him at his word. Let’s remember that above all, these two were cousins, and worked together in a band for about 15 years by the time this song was first released. Furthermore, the entire band, including Brian’s very own brothers were involved in the song.

In the late 60s, Brian had a mental breakdown, was fighting psychological and addictive demons, and was unable to function as masterfully as he did in the early and mid 60s. Having said that, Brian at 10% easily surpasses 90% of musicians at their best. Regardless, there was a big marketing push in the late 70s to claim – quite literally – “Brian’s back”. In other words, he’s no longer 300 pounds, addicted to amphetamines and lying in bed all day. It was an altogether insulting and offensive campaign which achieved nothing other than to increasingly add undue pressure upon Brian’s fragile psyche and set him up for certain failure.

I belive Mike wrote this from his heart, and in it he suggests that Brian’s been here all along, whether the public acknowledged him or not. As stated above, Love haters begrudge this after-the-fact, denial of having been part of the Brian pressurizers, and that may in fact be a valid point, but I still believe his words are coming from a place of deep respect and love. It may in fact be his way of apologizing or showing some regret, notwitstanding their legal battles that were yet to come. And even if it isn’t, at the very least, he’s giving voice to many who did feel that way, which is never a bad thing.

songs.full_title: Tears in the Morning by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Tears in the Morning

description.plain: “Tears in the Morning” is a song written by Bruce Johnston for the American rock band The Beach Boys. It was released on their 1970 album Sunflower. It was also released as a single, with the B-side of the single being “It’s About Time”. The single reached the top 5 in the Netherlands, the top 10 in Belgium, and did not chart in the US or the UK.

songs.full_title: I'm in Great Shape by The Beach Boys
songs.title: I’m in Great Shape

description.plain:
“I’m In Great Shape” is a section of music written by Brian Wilson and Van Dyke Parks for the aborted Beach Boys' album Smile. This section of music was originally intended to be 1 of 4 parts contained in a track Wilson referred to as the “Barnyard Suite”. It was also considered as a part for an earlier version of “Heroes and Villains”, a version which also contained the “Barnyard” section.

“I’m In Great Shape” is about waking up early in the morning, eating breakfast and heading out excitedly into the great American “open country”.

Although vocal overdubs were held for this track, none have ever been found. However, as of December 2018, a string overdub for the track has been unearthed and included as a bonus snippet in the final track of the Beach Boys' compilation album: 1968: Wake the World.

songs.lyrics:
[Verse 1]
An eagle's nest on the head of an old redwood on one of the
Precipice-footed ridges above Ventana Creek
That jagged country which nothing but a fallen meteor will ever plow:
No horseman will ever ride there, and no hunter cross this ridge but the winged ones
No one will steal the eggs from this fortress
The she-eagle is old, her mate was shot long ago, she is now mated with a son of hers
When lightning blasted her nest she built it again on the same tree, in the splinters of the thunder bolt

In a broken shack an old man takes his time about dying
And just at the back a wild flowerbed that he'll lie in
In dawn's new light a man might venture
A horse drawn stage from Monterey

[Verse 2]
The she-eagle is older than I: she was here when the fires of eighty-five raged on these ridges
She was lately fledged and dared not hunt ahead of them, but ate scorched meat
The world has changed in her time; humanity has multiplied
But not here; men's hopes and thoughts and customs have changed, their powers are enlarged, their powers and their follies have become fantastic

Spilled down the hill a wagon load of bodies lay scattered, shipwrecked at sea
Limestone ore is all that mattered
They took it from the hills right through the cargo doors
How many ships have come and gone at Thurso's landing shore?

[Verse 3]
The unstable animal never has been changed so rapidly
The motor and the plane and the great war have gone over him
And Lenin has lived and Jehovah died: while the mother-eagle hunts her same hills, crying the same beautiful and lonely cry
And is never tired: dreams the same dreams
And hears at night the rock-slides rattle and thunder in the
Throats of these living mountains
It is good for man to try all changes, progress and corruption, powers, peace and anguish
Not to go down the dinosaur's way until all his capacities have been explored: and it is good for him
To know that his needs and nature are no more changed, in fact, in ten thousand years than the beaks of eagles
Of the eagle's plight, we know that nature's balance is undone
And it's the birthright of man to unify and live his life as one
A whisper of the word will let you soar with your soulEmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

Break breakaway
Now I'm free to do what I want to do

[Verse 1]

Time is my destiny
Why change the part of me that has to be free
The love that passed me by
I found no reason why
But now each day is filled with the love
That very same love
That passed me by
And that is why
I can breakaway from that lonely life
And I can do what I want to do

[Verse 2]

Where the shackles never hold me down
I'm going to make a way for each happy day
As my life turns around

[Bridge][x2]
Come on we're free to breakaway
(Oh boy you jump for joy)
Now won't you come on
(When you breakaway)
You're free to breakaways

[Outro][x2]

songs.full_title: Getcha Back by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Getcha Back

description.plain:
“Getcha Back” is a song by the american rock band The Beach Boys. It was released on the 8th of May, 1985 as a single and on June 10 the same year in their 25th album, The Beach Boys. This was their first album since the death of founding member Dennis Wilson. It was produced by the producer of English band, Culture Club, Steve Levine. Lead vocals are sung by Mike Love and Brian Wilson with backing vocals by the rest of the band.

Music Video:

A promotional music video was released for the song. It features The Beach Boys, but the band members act as characters for the story and do not sing or play the song.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YAZBbZ27xlM

Single Art:

songs.full_title: Barnyard by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Barnyard

description.plain: “Barnyard” is a section of music written by Brian Wilson and Van Dyke Parks for the Beach Boys' aborted studio album Smile. It was originally intended to be 1 of 4 parts contained in a track Wilson referred to as the “Barnyard Suite”. It was also considered as a part for an earlier version of “Heroes and Villains”, a version which also contained the “I’m In Great Shape” section. Although many vocal sessions were held for this section, the only remains of them are background vocals and animal noises made by Brian Wilson’s entourage.

songs.full_title: Don't Back Down by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Don’t Back Down

description.plain: The last of the Beach Boys' songs about surfers, at least until the 80s. Ironically, the title was initially misprinted as “Don’t Break Down” when the album was released in 1964; that same year, Brian Wilson would stop touring with the Beach Boys after a severe panic attack.

songs.full_title: The Night Was So Young by The Beach Boys
songs.title: The Night Was So Young

description.plain: This beautiful and demure little song boasts several brilliant details. Most astonishing is the soaring chorus and its attendant backing vocals. Also note the wonderfully up front and reasonant bass line which nudges the song along. I am unaware of any song displaying bass with such a prominent and unique timbre that predates this one. Peter Hook used it to magnificent, in fact, career-defining effect in his work with Joy Division and New Order.

songs.full_title: Cotton Fields (The Cotton Song) by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Cotton Fields (The Cotton Song)

description.plain: This version was identified by the Beach Boys themselves as a cover of the Lead Belly song of the same name, but there are quite a few differences. First, the Beach Boys completely revamped the tone, opting for a more energized, “wall of sound” approach, in contrast to Lead Belly’s thin acoustic. Secondly, quite a few lyrics were changed. Naturally, the Beach Boys had to throw some lines about girls and SoCal in there.

songs.full_title: Gee by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Gee

description.plain:
“Gee” is a doo-wop song written my William Davis and Morris Levy.
It was originally released by the American R&B group “The Crows” in 1953 and has been credited as the first rock and roll hit by a rock and roll group.

Brian used this song to introduce the American spirit, very present in this album.

songs.full_title: Let Him Run Wild by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Let Him Run Wild

description.plain:
Let Him Run Wild" is a song written by Brian Wilson and Mike Love for the American rock band the Beach Boys. It was released on their 1965 album Summer Days (And Summer Nights!!) and as the B-side to “California Girls”.

Sibling bandmates Carl and Dennis Wilson later praised the song, calling it the point where they began to take notice of Brian’s abilities. It was one of the first songs that Brian wrote while under the influence of marijuana.

Source https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Let_Him_Run_Wild

songs.full_title: California Saga (Big Sur) by The Beach Boys
songs.title: California Saga (Big Sur)

description.plain:
“California Saga: Big Sur” is the third track on Holland by The Beach Boys and the first track in their California Saga. Written by Mike Love, it is one of the few songs he has a solo credit for.

On the song, Mike emulates a classic American Country sound, with evocative lyrics about the countryside.

body.plain:
“California Saga: Big Sur” is the third track on Holland by The Beach Boys and the first track in their California Saga. Written by Mike Love, it is one of the few songs he has a solo credit for.

On the song, Mike emulates a classic American Country sound, with evocative lyrics about the countryside.

songs.lyrics:
[Verse]
Cashmere hills filled with evergreens
Flowin' from the clouds down to meet the sea
With the granite cliff as a referee
Crimson sunsets and golden dawns
Mother deer with their newborn fawns
Under Big Sur skies and that's where I belong

[Chorus]
Big Sur I've got plans for you
Me and mine are going to
Add ourselves to your lengthy list of lovers

[Verse]
And live in canyons covered with a springtime green
While birds and flowers to be heard and seen
And on my old guitar I'll make up songs to sing
Sparklin' springs from the mountainside
Join the Big Sur river rushing to the tide
Where my kids can search for sea shells at low tide

[Chorus]
Big Sur, my astrology
It says that I am meant to be
Where the rugged mountain meets the water
[Verse]
And so while stars shine brightly and up above
Fog rolls in through a redwood grove
And to my dying fire I think I'll add a logEmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.full_title: County Fair by The Beach Boys
songs.title: County Fair

description.plain:
County Fair is the second song on the Surfin' Safari Album released in 1962.

In the song, the singer takes his girlfriend to the county fair, trying to win a prize for her. After not winning any prizes in different games, the girl falls for a stronger guy, who can actually ring the bell in a game of high striker.

album.full_title: Surfin' Safari by The Beach Boys
album.name: Surfin’ Safari

annotatable.link_title: County Fair by The Beach Boys
annotatable.title: County Fair

body.plain:
County Fair is the second song on the Surfin' Safari Album released in 1962.

In the song, the singer takes his girlfriend to the county fair, trying to win a prize for her. After not winning any prizes in different games, the girl falls for a stronger guy, who can actually ring the bell in a game of high striker.

songs.lyrics:
[Verse 1: The Beach Boys]
This time each year in our hometown
The county fair comes our way
Where the folks gather round to be happy and spend their day
A-here's what happened now
I soon decide that I'd take with me
The most specialest girl I knew
I had her pack us a lunch and on down the dirt road we flew

[Verse 2: County Fair Folk & Girl]
Folk: "Hurry hurry, step right up and win your girl a stuffed koala bear!"
Girl: "Aw, come on Nicky, win me a koala bear!"
Folk: "Break the balloon with a dart! Yes, you son, come up here! Win your girl a stuffed koala bear!
Girl: "Oh please, win me a koala bear!"
Folk: "Break the balloon with a dart! Come on son, step right up! Get up there, that's a boy!"

[Verse 3: The Beach Boys]
Right then I knew what I had to do
(Hurry, hurry)
Before that day was through
(Step right up)
I had to win a stuffed doggie or I'd break her poor heart in two
(Hurry, hurry)
(Win a prize)
A-let me tell you now
I passed up a chance when I walked by a booth
(Hurry, hurry)
Where you throw a dart and break a balloon
(Step right up)
I snuck by a couple more, but I had to get caught real soon
(Hurry, hurry)
(Win a prize)
[Verse 4: County Fair Folk & Girl]
Folk: "Step right up, test your strength! Come on, son, ring the bell with the hammer!"
Girl: "Aww, come on, muscles!"
Folk: "Win your girl a stuffed koala bear!"
Girl: "Ooohhh"
Folk: "Come on son, are you a man or a weakling? Yes, you, step up here and test your strength! Win your girl a stuffed koala bear!"
Girl: "Come on, baby!"
Folk: "Come on, son!"

[Verse 5: The Beach Boys]
I hit the rubber stump just as hard as I could
(Hurry, hurry)
But I didn't make it ring the bell
(Step right up)
I tried again and again, but I just didn't do so well
(Hurry, hurry)
(Win a prize)
Can you believe it now
Up walked a fellow and he tapped me on the shoulder, said
(Hurry, hurry)
"I can win your girl a prize"
(Step right up)
So he flexed all his muscles and he knocked the bell up in the sky
(Hurry, hurry)
(Win a prize)
[Verse 6: The Beach Boys & Fair County Folk & Girl]
Yeah the big strong guy knocked the bell in the sky
(Hurry, hurry)
Took my girl and the doggie away
(Step right up)
Yeah the big strong guy knocked the bell in the sky
(Folk: "Step right up son, test your strength!")
Took my girl and the doggie away
(Folk: "Come on kid, ring the bell!")
Yeah the big strong guy knocked the bell in the sky
(Girl: "Ah, goodbye, muscles, I don't need you anymore")
Took my girl and the doggie away
(Girl: "Loser!")
Yeah the big strong guy knocked the bell in the sky
(Girl: "Forget it!")EmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.full_title: Wonderful (Smile Version) by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Wonderful (Smile Version)

description.plain:
Music historian Mark Dillon interprets the lyrics to be the story of a girl devoted to God and her parents who is thrown into emotional disarray after encountering a boy.

Biographer Andrew Hickey similarly describes the song as the story of a young woman and her steadfast embrace of adolescence through the loss of her own virginity.
He characterized the original version of the recording as “proto-psychedelic chamber pop”.

songs.full_title: Chug-A-Lug by The Beach Boys
songs.title: Chug-A-Lug

description.plain:
A surf-rock tune about going to the beach with pals and getting some root beer.

Beach Boys historian Domenic Priore says this song “is filled with great bass vocals from Mike and a fun chorus… just the kind of record that could have been a hit had Capitol followed Brian’s instincts. It also has a hot guitar solo, and the lyric really cues you into the personalities of the individual Beach Boys.”

songs.lyrics:
Stark naked in front of my mirror
A pudgy person somehow did appear
Seems lately all I've eaten sugar and fat
It's getting obvious that's not where it's at
A big pot and tripley chin
Oh what condition my condition was in
Laughing at myself at what a crying shame
What ever happened to my Greek godly frame

Cyclamates juicy steaks, sweet things too
Aren't always good as they seem
Doughy lumps, stomach pumps, enemas too
That's what you get when you eat that way

I read a book on organic foods
Jumped on a health food kick
Put me in the mood
You may not get to perfect overnight
But on the way you're feelin' clean out of sight
We ate tonight at Fairfax and 3rd
We're gonna spread the news and give you the word
We hope that soon you'll eat like we did today
We're mighty thankful now that H.E.L.P.'s on its way
Salad with a special knock you right off your seat
With carrot juice to wash it all down
Yummy carob cookies are an organic treat
And H.E.L.P. has got the best food in town
H.-E.-L.-P
H.E.L.P. your education creates much benefit and peace

Hamburgers and hot dogs throw 'em all out
You'll feel so good you'll jump up and shout
If you haven't why don't you go shopping today
And 'member now that H.E.L.P. 's on its way

H.-E.-L.-P
Radiant Radish is gonna be on Fairfax and 3rd
Sansasanth and Melrose 40452
Oooh, get yourself in for a snack
Yeah, but stop by the Radiant RadishEmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy
